article:
The 'pseudorange' (from and ) is the pseudo 
distance between a satellite and a navigation satellite receiver (see GNSS
positioning calculation) âfor instance Global Positioning System (GPS)
receivers.

To determine its position, a satellite navigation receiver will determine the
ranges to (at least) four satellites as well as their positions at time of
transmitting. Knowing the satellites' orbital parameters, these positions can be
calculated for any point in time. The pseudoranges of each satellite are
obtained by multiplying the speed of light by the time the signal has taken from
the satellite to the receiver. As there are accuracy errors in the time
measured, the term pseudo-ranges is used rather than ranges for such distances.
